pros: Flexible hours and interesting project
cons: Not any cons in this.

job_title: Senior IT Administrator in Bath, England
pros: Friendly people, lovely campus, remote working, varied work, opportunities to work with a wide variety of technology, excellent pension (compared to most private sector offerings).
cons: Pay below market rate with high staff turnover and lots of people in IT leaving for Bristol Uni. As its higher education, everything has to be debated to the n'th degree and sometimes its not clear who is in charge and who is setting the direction. The department is going through a big transformation (termed, evolution) which keeps thing interesting but I sense it may be a struggle for some to get onboard.

cons: Pay Culture Hierarchical structure Management communication Career progression

review_title: Decent pay and opportunity to fit hours around studies
pros: As far as fitness instructing roles go, this pays well for those wanting to pick up a few hours of work a week alongside their studies. There are lots of hours available, being open from 6 am to 10 pm. Likeminded people with a general interest in health and fitness to work with, so a great environment,
cons: There is a weird push for old school exercise classes and a resistance to change their fitness class program schedule to what people actually want at the current time.

review_title: Welcome to the High School of Bath
job_title: PhD student/ Post Doc Research Accociate in Bath, England
pros: If you are lucky, research can be interesting if you work with good academics. If you are willing to wait 1.5 years on waiting list, Westwood Nursery is very good. The gym is amazing and there is plenty of green space to walk and collect you're thoughts.
cons: Availability and quality of food is awefull. When the students are away (out of semester time), the outlets are reduce the food quality and availability to North Korea standards. This essentially reflects the contempt of the VC to his employees. The VC is obsessed with his own image and his decisions are always aimed at how he is seen rather than how they affect his employees. VC is mothballing research and turning the University into a high school.

pros: collegial and supportive place to work

review_title: Glad I got to work here

review_title: Good perks but terrible career progression

pros: Fantastic campus location. Some individually supportive members of staff.
cons: A university where I never felt welcome nor respected. Comically I was handed a redundancy notice the same week I was given an award for being the outstanding research staff member of my pay grade. The university handled redundancy without any grace. They didn't even proof read the redundancy notice giving me three "moths" of notice, ending on "Augsut". The exit interview was an online survey with multiple choice questions asking why I was leaving. The cherry on top was when they sent my P45 to my old university office, the one and only address they could confirm I don't have access too. The entire experience was insulting.

review_title: Best HEI I ever worked at

cons: None I can think of.

review_title: Don't do it - School of Management
pros:
Nice campus
Lovely doctoral community
cons:
Abusive supervisors - expect you to work >50hrs per week for peanuts. There is nothing you can do about it because their mates will be your examiners.
Departments are super diverse - but not when you look at senior management - they are all white British and male. 
It's super hard for women to get promoted at the school - the standards are just different - in my department two male PhD students were made assistant profs without even having their PhDs completed. The two women that were made assistant profs had several years of post-doc and multiple publications... yet all started off at the same salary.... overall summary: don't go there! (especially not if you're a woman)

pros: -small campus means more intimate feel -high graduate opportunities and careers-focused: 2/3 students complete a placement year.

cons:
1. Can feel a bit lost / lonely at the start with so much to learn in the job and not the right support available 
2. workload is very challenging in the first 12 months 
3. Very low pay in comparison to industry but better than other univeristies

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bath, England
pros: Good pay, flexible hours mostly
cons: Management need to invest in current students, rather than wasting money on vanity projects and buildings

review_title: Extreme left politics and the power of. "yes-men"
pros: The campus feel is quite nice. Many staff want to help students and make the environment better for creating graduates ready for the outside world. The ambition is there.
cons: Ambition is not considered a positive trait. Ideas are not wanted unless they are extremely "progressive" and based on extreme left-wing philosophies. Heads of Departments are only put in place if they are "yes-men" and they surround themselves with "yes-men". Those who buck the trend for the right reasons are prevented from growing, or progressing their career in anyway. Experts are forced to teach topics unrelated to their field, and are then targeted because their OUE (online unit evaluation) scores (from students) are below an arbitrary figure. The place is toxic at times. The ones who care tend to pull away from integrating into the departments too well. If they voice their concerns they are considered "trouble makers", but there are many of them.

review_title: Good for undergrads, one of the worst for postgrads
pros:
Happy and noisy undergrads
Uni has money and seem to be expanding
Good sport facilities and societies
Beautiful town with lots of parks and old buildings
Close to lively and cosmopolitan Bristol
cons:
Support for postgrads to succeed in academia is almost nonexistent, most of the postgrads have no idea on what they are missing until its very late. Most of PhDs struggle to find a job even out of academia.
Racism and sexism are more prevalent than other 3 campus I experienced in UK
Our department, Biology and Biochemistry, is very crowded and there are ongoing wars over lab space while uni builds more accommodations and a building for art and societies to keep undergrads happy! I've heard similar stories from couple of other departments.

Rent and commodities are quite expensive as town's main industry is tourism everything is a bit more expensive. 
Town is awfully crowded during weekends and any holiday, residents are mainly elderly conservatives.

* If you are a postgrad or a post-doc consider all your options and research uni's record on postgrad satisfaction and reports on quality of research

job_title: Accommodation Operations Deputy Team Leader in Bath, England
pros: The whole package you get working for the university is excellent. Not do you only have all the Christmas break plus all bank holidays off the University reward us with further concessionary days, there is even subsidised parking for staff. They offer great support to the staff, both through your professional role with ongoing training and progression opportunities which is what I have done but also personally if you need welfare support. We have summer fetes and Christmas party's, social evenings and events organised on by the social committee plus coffee mornings for charity. The varied roles are quite extensive, some in retail, hospitality, security or accommodation on the operational side plus of course the educational side. Its a job of two halves, we have students during term times and then in the summer we operate as a huge hotel and conference centre so there is never a dull moment.
cons: Weekend working in some areas is required.

pros: Campus has a nice buzz and they're constantly investing in it. My boss is fantastic and has given me space to work on my own things as well as the main project. Pay is fixed by research council but postdoc pay in general is pretty good these days. Good investment in uni-wide resources such as high performance computing. In fact computer services in general are fantastic and quite forward looking.
cons: It is quite a small university which can mean that you are a little isolated if you're not in a big group. Career progression is not easy (although postdoc -> lecturer never is) partly because they regard experience in Bath as inferior to higher ranking universities. Some hiring from within does occur.

pros: Located in the beautiful historical city of Bath (although the campus design is from a whole another era), sounds impressive and grand, new sport facilities (including a proper track and field), flexible working
cons:
Review based on experience from 2 departments:
Lack of collegiate atmosphere but be prepared for lots of politics, cliques and narcissist-type of behaviour. Colleagues speak of the working environment as toxic and vile. High staff turnover common, as well as staff off sick due to stress and depression. 
I have witnessed unprofessional behaviour by management, including some appalling examples of bullying of PhD students by supervisors. Also witnessed bullying and harassment-type of behaviour by management allowed and covered up by other management and HR.

review_title: It opened my mind to various placements and gave me the skills to get an internship at Microsoft!
pros: The University has extremely good facilities; in terms of science and sports. It pushes people to grow and develop, therefore granting access to the world through knowledge, confidence and contacts. I am happy to have come here!
cons: The majority of people there have been spoon-fed all of their lives and know nothing about struggle; full of pretentious people. I think that the University should advertise themselves to less-economically developed schools around the country. The work load in engineering is about double the stated workload.

review_title: Dream job in a great organisation
pros: I have worked in a number of HE institutions over many years, and Bath stands out for me as an exceptional place to work. The campus is beautiful and the people are great to work with - colleagues who have a genuine will and drive to be collaborative. We have wonderful students who are making a difference in the world. I love my job and feel very lucky to work here. There has been a noticeable difference in culture recently and the organisation has responded well to the COVID pandemic as a result.
cons: There can be lots of hoops to jump through to get things done, but this is typical in HE.

review_title: Satisfied with research, not the best place with politicsa
pros: It is a very good place for a researcher. A lot of opportunities for meetinggs and travells, not far away from large centers (1.5 hour to London, 15 min to Bristol by train). So you have a chance for often research contacts with other universities (much more then in other countries usually).
cons: If you are not lucky enouph to have a people with similar research interests in Bath, you would feel pretty isolated as the university is not large. In case of any conflict with a boss, it is better to leave quickly,  situation has no chance to improve as the uni is like small village.

pros: Great facilities and a very green campus make it a nice environment to work in.  Lots of events going on and great reputation.  Lots of opportunities for development.  Plenty of interesting research and people.  Definitely good if you like sport.
cons: Communication can be a little poor at times.  Internal politics can be an issue.  If relocating to work here then transport and accommodation can be a little difficult in Bath, depending on your circumstances.

pros: A compact campus on the edge of a very nice small city. The university does a lot of good research, and I was allowed freedom to pursue my own project.
cons: The Post-Graduate Skills training was exasperating - pitched far too low, fixated on superficial presentation and lacking discussion of hard science. The presence of courses based on long debunked pseudoscience should not be accepted in a serious research university. (This however is a UK-wide problem).

review_title: I would not recommend working here as it will not help your career progress
pros:
- Bath is a beautiful location even though the university looks completely outdated and should be build from the ground up again.
- They do give you flexibility in working hours and working from home
- Some people here are very friendly a lot of them are just out for themselves. 
- Research ethics are something they mostly ignore especially in regards to authors and how much they actually contribute might be different between departments.

Most are negatives and after 2 years of employment that is not good.
cons:
- Public transport is bad waiting time 1+ hour min to leave or get to uni
- Parking is bad, they force you to pay but put the parking so far from office its like its off campus there time when you need to walk 15 to 20 min from car to office
- accessibility to the university is very difficult to begin with regardless if you try and reach it by car or public transport. 
- Cannot use the sport facility as employee without paying 50 pounds per month (as student you can get a cheaper subscription to sports facilities than employee)
- No free of even discount on coffee or anything product as employee 
- No benefits at all 
- Facilities in most of departments are outdated
- Getting money to go to conference made unbelievable difficult 
- No job progression
- Made very difficult for research project to spend money on the project itself uni will force you to spend the research money on estates and other stuff which the university will directly pocket itself.
- Forcing researchers to do task for universities while they are getting paid from research grants. (these tasks are not beneficial in any way to these researchers)

review_title: Community campus delivering excellent teaching and research
pros: friendly and ambitious staff doing fantastic research, always willing to start new collaborations; capable enthusiastic students who care about using their education to do great things; amazing compact campus with all the sports facilitates and walking routes you could wish for; absolutely stunning surrounding countryside; good range of food outlets many very aware of environmental and social concerns.
cons: Bath is small and beautiful so gets very busy, this means commuting and travelling around by car and public transport can be slow in rush hour.

pros:
*  Very beautiful city.
* University sells pretty much all you need for your day to day.
* Could be fun if enrolled in a different course as there are many activities and clubs to join.
cons:
* Expensive city.
* Low quality lectures.
* No work life balance, 100% work.
*  You will spend most of your precious time resorting to higher quality universities free materials and online lectures.
* You should be very comfortable with Python and Statistics beforehand.
* Course design is weak and will try to cover as much material as possible with no optional units despite what the website says.
* You can skip most of the lectures and probably learn more on your own.

job_title: Open Day Helper in Bath, England
pros: I was paid on time, although on the day I worked I had just missed a payroll day so had to wait for the next month. However this was all explained at the time and sure enough it came through on time. The atmosphere at Bath University is very friendly and the campus is beautiful.
cons: The campus buildings aren't as nice as the city centre, though they are functional.  However it is well landscaped and very green.

pros: The University has a good reputation, it sounds impressive to future employers.  The location is great, there are new buildings, the students are smart.
cons: Management is terrible, corrupt.  I have been threatened by my line manager, and too scared to report him.  There are loads of politics, loads of bad practice.  Trying to get by with less than is essential.  The food on campus is terrible, and closes during summer.  This was all in sports/education.

pros: Very supportive and creative environment  - able to share space with leading academics and professionals.  Can be very open to ideas from all levels of team  - will listen to problem solving ideas and actually put them in to practice.
cons: Low pay for standard of work expected. Digitally backwards in some departments.  Can be left to self manage a little too much.

pros: Very friendly and supportive culture. The campus is beautiful.  The staff is very help as well as the technicians. The Library is 24 hours open and has many media facilities.
cons: The university is too far away from city center. The campus is beautiful but too small. Do not have so many equipments.

job_title: Business Engagement Manager in Bath, England
pros: The University is a good employer, and strives to provide flexibility and a positive work-life balance. Academic colleagues and students are passionate about making a positive difference in the world which creates a good atmosphere and pride in our work. There is a new commitment to climate action and to playing a positive role in the local community.
cons: High workload during peak periods, e.g. autumn.

pros: I get 12% holiday pay for every shift as a student part time. Flexible timetable. Can get a lot of shifts during the week. No overtime.
cons: Short lunch time break (30 min), unhygienic coffee machine, lack of training, can be extremely packed. They use a tablet for Rota, so you have to be sharp for clock ins.

pros: Good opportunity, good culture, great people, beautiful city with great people, good campus, strong NSS
cons: The financially not rewarding, especially with zero-contract, feels not been appreciated as much as you should, extremely expensive to live and rent, limited accommodation with high price, public transport from town centre to university is a horrible, there is not enough parking space

review_title: A wonderful place to study and work
pros:
Friendly environment 
Supportive 
Quality of education 
The city, Bath, is very beautiful and friendly. 
I highly recommend this place for work and study
cons:
The pay rate is not as good as it should be.
The staff room is not very big and some buildings are still old, though some renovations are happening!

pros: Unsupervised. Can come and go as we please. Very little monitoring on work done. Well paid.
cons: Demotivating environment. Any attempts at taking initiative is mocked. Line manager will postpone meeting for months. Contradictory requests.

review_title: A very good university  with reputation. highest satisfaction in UK. Probably because it's a small-scale campus uni.
job_title: Chair of Postgraduate Assiciation in Bath, England
pros: Pretty Campus, engaging Student Union, a lots of events going on on a daily basis.
cons: Library , always busy, lunchtime could be the worst time. The food supply is not good as expected

review_title: One of the nicest places to work in Bath
job_title: Digital Content Editor in Bath, England
pros: Great benefits - the holiday is generous, two small pay rises a year, good sick pay and maternity pay.
cons: Having to pay for parking. Salary discrepancy between lowest and highest paid members of staff is ridiculous.

pros: Friendly Colleagues; Good Work-Life balance; Allowance for personal projects; Immediate management is very reasonable and understanding.
cons:
Higher tier management is difficult to approach.
Expenditure on Technicians is dwindling and empty positions are not being filled.
HR sticks to policy even when it defies common sense in my personal opinion.

pros: Struggling to find anything good about working here
cons:
The University of Bath  do not deal with bullying or harassment seriously
There is not structure for PhD students - at the will of supervisor
There was zero introduction of effort made to make new employees feel welcome

pros: Excellent atmosphere, very good students, ambitious university, beautiful surroundings
cons:
Long semesters with practically no break without them
Requires full commitment and hard work
Very student focused, teaching is an important part of the workload while research excellence is also required

pros: major why I dont like to write a lot is ti enough now?
cons: The lack of classmates major why I dont like to write a lot is ti enough now?

pros:
Extremely student friendly environment
The professors are well qualified and are easily approachable 
The course structure is well curated
cons: Few post graduate course don't have balance between the assignments and the number of exams. Since it is a 2 year programme, it is hectic

pros: Friendly staff and compact campus means it's relatively easy to access all areas.  Well respected Uni with good student intakes.
cons: Salaries for many roles are poor for the sector and area.  Not really much in the way of benefits.

review_title: Flexible hours, fun job and good for networking
pros:
required to work around 9 hours a week which is ideal to balance with academic life
get to talk to some really interesting people
cons: towards the end became a bit boring due to few people answering your calls

job_title: Casual Food and Beverage Assistant in Bath, England
pros:
- Casual contract which pays well so you can earn some extra money during your studies
- Nice staff and many other students work there so it is a nice environment to work in
cons: - Management is not the best

review_title: If I had been in a department, it would have held my interested.  I was in a support office, which did not.
pros: Freedom, independence, scope of the University.
cons: Absolute, dogmatic lack of progression.

review_title: Pleasant but could do with more sparks
pros: Beautiful campus in relaxing city with good connections to vibrant cities of Bristol and London.
cons:
- Some transport issues sometimes (getting up the hill).
- Could incentivise an environment to foster more cross-disciplinary/department interactions.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Bath, England
pros: Small safe and wealthy city, decent university facilities
cons: Poor support for Postgraduate researchers, generally left alone when things go bad. Management is terrible and handled the recent Covid-19 process in a disastrous way. Behavior of staff is not satisfactory for what one would expect. There are better universities to choose from if you want to do a PhD, I would not pick this one.

pros: Excellent technical testing facilities and personel
cons: After 3 years you are more or less forced to leave as they stop paying you. You even start paying fees from that point. But that is common in the UK.

review_title: Not great for career progression in academia
pros:
Comfortable city
Good post for PhD graduates with no teaching experience
cons:
Teaching load is onerous
You will have no time to work for publications
No systematic career development support for early career researchers in this post.

review_title: Good job for part time work at university
pros:
Very high pay for the job
Can easily fit in with your timetable
cons: Upper management can be a bit clueless and somewhat snooty but you don’t see them too often

review_title: Bath is a very nice place to work in,the people are friendly
pros: people are friendly and the environment is conducive
cons: Bath is very small,and the social life is abit lacking

pros: Fantastic culture; everyone wants to do a great job. So many benefits, and working on a campus is great.
cons: it is challenging to park if you arrive after 9 am

pros: Generous overtime pay and good flexibility
cons: Shift work which is difficult for some who have to balance other commitments, however, this is compensated for with extra pay

pros: Decent pay, overtime hours available
cons: one deputy team leader who doesn't know what she is doing. Passing stress onto staff members.

pros:
professional and organised administration
relocation allowance (up to 1 month gross salary)
high level research and education
modern campus, great catering

pros: Great setting for the campus and brilliant city
cons: Everything is about trying to squeeze as much money as they can from each student

review_title: Great pay, flexible hours, social benefits

cons: Working Wednesday night club shifts

pros: Lovely campus and great facilities for working at. Lots of food venues to choose from and good transport options.

pros: As a student, it is very convenient and accessible to work with the team at Bath.

pros: I was offered an adequate amount of classes based on my experience.
cons: Of course, it would be great if there were more opportunities!

pros: Very flexible, friendly environment. The team I worked with was great

pros: Lots of fun working with students and academics, good atmosphere, great sport facilities.

review_title: It's a mixed bag for the future
